column1: Câmpulung Moldovenesc (also spelled Cîmpulung Moldovenesc; Romanian pronunciation: [kɨmpuˌluŋɡ moldoveˈnesk]) is a city in Suceava County
column2: north-eastern Romania. It is situated in the historical region of Bukovina.

column1: Câmpulung Moldovenesc is the fourth largest urban settlement in the county
column4: according to the 2011 census. It was declared a municipality in 1995
column5: along with two other cities in Suceava County: Fălticeni and Rădăuți. Câmpulung Moldovenesc covers an area of 147 km² and it was the capital of former Câmpulung County (until 1950).

column1: == Other names ==
The city is also known as Hosszúmező in Hungarian

column1: == Geography ==
Câmpulung Moldovenesc is situated in the region of Bukovina
column2: in north-eastern Romania. The city is located in the mountain area of Obcinele Bucovinei
column3: on the banks of the Moldova River.

column1: Câmpulung Moldovenesc is accessible by both car and train. The European route E58
column2: that links the region of Moldavia with Transylvania
column3: crosses the city. There are two railway stations located in the city: Câmpulung Moldovenesc in the city center and Câmpulung Est in Capu Satului neighborhood.

column1: There are many places of interest located in and around Câmpulung Moldovenesc
column3: which at 1650 meters and 1857 meters are the highest peaks in the region. One can also enjoy the forests which surround Câmpulung Moldovenesc or visit a monastery in one of the nearby villages.

column1: == History ==
The first written mention of the village of Câmpulung Moldovenesc dates back to April 14
column2: 1411. At that time the ruling prince of Moldavia was Alexandru cel Bun. Dimitrie Cantemir
column3: in his well-known work Descriptio Moldaviae
column5: an autonomous region in northern Moldavia that has its own rules and leaders. This region consisted of 15 villages.

column1: Together with the rest of Bukovina
column2: Câmpulung Moldovenesc was under the rule of the Habsburg Monarchy (later Austria-Hungary) from 1775 to 1918. Câmpulung was in the Austrian part of the empire after the compromise of 1867
column3: head of the district with the same name
column4: one of the 9 Bezirkshauptmannschaften in Bukovina province. Other main district cities were Dorna Watra (Vatra Dornei) and Wama (Vama) in 1900.Later
column6: Câmpulung Moldovenesc was the capital of the former Câmpulung County
column7: the most extensive county in Bukovina. The spa and ski resort Vatra Dornei was the second most important town in Câmpulung County.

column1: == Demographics ==
Câmpulung Moldovenesc reached its peak population in 1992
column3: 000 people were living within the city limits. As of 2016
column4: the town of Câmpulung Moldovenesc is the fourth largest urban settlement in Suceava County
column7: and the larger towns of Rădăuți and Fălticeni.At the 2011 census
column8: Câmpulung Moldovenesc had a population of 16
column9: 105 inhabitants: 99.08% of inhabitants were ethnic Romanians

column1: == Economy ==
The main industries in Câmpulung Moldovenesc are dairy products
column3: and ecotourism. Part of the city inhabitants works in agriculture and bovine growth.

column1: Câmpulung means "Long Field" in Romanian. Moldovenesc ("Moldavian") is used to differentiate between this city and Câmpulung Muscel (Argeș County
